headline: Jenkins: Nixon's Lesson for Obama on AT&T
summary: There's a lot to be said for presidential oversight of antitrust actions.

headline: Obama Administration to Defend Solyndra Loan
summary: The Obama administration, in testimony before a congressional committee on Wednesday, plans to defend its support for solar-panel maker Solyndra, which filed for bankruptcy and is the target of a criminal investigation.

headline: Japan Frets Over Weak Value of Korean Won
summary: Japan's top trade negotiator expressed concern over South Korea's efforts to depress the value of the won, saying that the currency's relative weakness against the yen posed a "serious challenge" to Japanese industries.

headline: EBay Employees Under Criminal Probe
summary: Federal investigators are probing whether eBay employees misappropriated confidential information from online classified service Craigslist.

headline: Samsung, DoCoMo to Jointly Develop Smartphone Chips
summary: Samsung Electronics, NTT DoCoMo and Fujitsu Ltd. are in talks to set up a joint venture to develop semiconductors for smartphones.

headline: Southeast Asia in Pictures
summary: Protesters rally against a foreign mining company in the Philippines, people beg in Cambodia, officials destroy bundles of counterfeit money in Indonesia, and more.

headline: Oaktree Makes Unsolicited Bid for Jakks for More Than $650 Million
summary: Funds of Oaktree Capital Management are stepping up efforts to acquire toy maker Jakks, sending a letter to the company's board outlining a new proposal and building a stake in its stock.

headline: Deals India: Morning News Roundup
summary: News roundup from Indian newspapers, news wires and Web sites on Wednesday, September 14, 2011. Deals India has not verified the stories from other media organizations and does not vouch for their accuracy.

headline: Boeing Gets Favorable Safety Decision
summary: International safety experts cleared Boeing's latest 747 model to operate under the same air-traffic control rules and in-flight spacing restrictions as earlier jumbo jets.

headline: Russia Sets Launch to Maintain Crews on Space Station
summary: Russian space officials said they will resume manned flights to the International Space Station by mid November, a schedule intended to ensure uninterrupted crew presence aboard the orbiting laboratory.

headline: Attacks Rock Kabul
summary: Insurgents staged a series of attacks across Kabul on Tuesday, with rocket-propelled grenades, gunfire and suicide bombers targeting the U.S. Embassy, in one of the most brazen Taliban assaults on the Afghan capital.

headline: Silvercorp Shares Fall as New Allegations Surface
summary: Silvercorp Metals shares were down sharply Tuesday as anonymous allegations surface against the silver miner for the second time since late August.

headline: Caxton Founders Will Retire
summary: Caxton Associates LP said co-founders Bruce Kovner and Peter D'Angelo will retire from the $10 billion hedge fund at year-end and named Andrew Law as their successor.

headline: Muni Market Shrugs, for Now, at Possible Tax Hit
summary: The $2.9 trillion municipal-bond market held firm Tuesday, a day after President Obama proposed legislation to curtail the federal tax exemptions that have long underpinned the economics of muni-bond investments.

headline: Republican Tag Team
summary: Rick Perry's two main rivals went after him again at last night's Republican debate in Tampa, Fla., but they chose different issues on which to hammer the Texas governor.

headline: Peter J. Wallison: 'Grand Bargains' Are a Budgetary Dead End
summary: The arithmetic of debt is simple: The taxes necessary to feed these deals will stifle economic growth.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: Syndicated columnist Thomas Sowell writing on Obama's economic policies at townhall.com on Sept. 13.

headline: Leif Babin: We've Won in Iraq, So Let's Leave
summary: Leaving 3,000 U.S. troops there would only be an irritant.

headline: Sadanand Dhume: Pakistan's Low-Grade Civil War
summary: Anti-Shiite violence by Sunni extremists has been spreading.

headline: Venezuela Moves Up Presidential Vote Date
summary: Venezuela's elections board scheduled the country's 2012 presidential vote for Oct. 7, moving the contest up from its traditional December time frame, a move that some critics say gives President Hugo Chávez an edge.

headline: Dow Makes It Two in a Row
summary: Stocks notched a second consecutive day of gains, led by the industrial and technology sectors.

headline: Ford, UAW Extend Contract
summary: Ford and the United Auto Workers union agreed to temporarily extend terms of their existing labor contract past a Wednesday expiration to allow negotiations on a new contract to continue.

headline: FCC Seeks More LightSquared Testing
summary: Federal Communications Commission officials Tuesday said more testing is needed on wireless startup LightSquared's plan to deploy a new network that could cause interference with some GPS devices.

headline: Disaster-Relief Measure Clears Senate
summary: The Senate voted to advance a measure to fund disaster relief in the aftermath of Hurricane Irene, as eight Republicans broke with their caucus to join Democrats in support of providing immediate funding.

headline: E. Coli Types Slated for Testing Next Year Are Dangerous
summary: The six additional types of E. coli bacteria the U.S. Department of Agriculture said Monday it will begin testing for in beef next year can be just as dangerous as the one type it tests for now, USDA Secretary Tom Vilsack said Tuesday.

headline: Warren to Announce Bid for Senate Seat
summary: Elizabeth Warren, a Harvard Law professor and key architect of the U.S. Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, will announce on Wednesday that she is running for the U.S. Senate.

headline: Facebook to Organize Friends Into Lists
summary: Facebook unveiled a new feature that automatically puts users' friends into lists like work, school and family, as it moves to give users more control and compete with Google+.

headline: Soccer Sage
summary: None

headline: Nintendo Unveils Games; Falls 5%
summary: Trying to revitalize its struggling 3DS handheld console, Nintendo unveiled a raft of new games, including titles in popular franchises such as Mario, as well as products it says are designed to appeal to female consumers.

headline: Morgan Stanley Hires Former Fed Economist
summary: Morgan Stanley has hired former Federal Reserve economist Vincent Reinhart as chief U.S. economist, responsible for the firm's analysis of the U.S. economy.

headline: Oil Returns to $90
summary: U.S. crude-oil futures finished above $90 a barrel for the first time in more than a month Tuesday, as traders looked to a likely drop in U.S. oil inventories and shrugged off forecasts calling for weaker oil demand.

headline: Ex-AMD Manager Testifies of Providing Confidential Tips
summary: A former Advanced Micro Devices employee has testified that he gave confidential information about the chip maker to a sales manager and others at a so-called expert-network firm.

headline: Swaps Group Balks at Regulatory Changes
summary: The International Swaps and Derivatives Association said that regulatory changes proposed for the $600 trillion privately traded derivatives market may increase risk.

headline: Budget Deficit Running Below Last Year
summary: The U.S. budget deficit in the first 11 months of fiscal 2011 totaled $1.234 trillion, below the $1.26 trillion gap during the same period a year earlier, the Treasury Department said.

headline: Bearish Bank Bets '11 > Bearish Bank Bets '08
summary: Options-market investors have ramped up conditional bearish bets on financial stocks in recent weeks to an even greater degree than they did during the financial crisis three years ago, dividing market observers over whether the negativity is justified.

headline: Verizon to Push $50 Unlimited Prepaid Plan
summary: Verizon Wireless will introduce a new unlimited prepaid plan nationally this week, taking on rivals Sprint Nextel and MetroPCS as they continue to add customers seeking contract-free service.

headline: Sadanand Dhume: The Plight of Pakistan's Shia
summary: The country's largest religious minority is a bellwether for its struggle against radical Islam.

headline: Ex-SAC Manager Settles Insider Case
summary: Donald Longueuil, a former hedge-fund manager at SAC Capital Advisors, has agreed to pay more than $350,000 to settle an insider-trading lawsuit by the Securities and Exchange Commission that stemmed from a government probe into expert-network firms

headline: Cairn's Red Light in Greenland
summary: If you're an oil explorer, you had better find some oil. Cairn Energy's shares slumped by 9.1% Tuesday, after its second failure this summer to find commercially viable reserves in Greenland.

headline: House Panel Targets EPA Rules in Vote
summary: A House panel voted to delay two sets of EPA air-pollution rules affecting cement plants and industrial and commercial boilers by 15 months.

headline: Bank of America May Lose Bankers in India
summary: Seven investment bankers in India are among the 30,000 employees that Bank of America Corp. is expected to layoff, according to sources including a bank official with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline: Gold Ends Higher
summary: A lower dollar coupled with worrying developments in Europe halted gold's   slide. Futures reversed course after a brief dip below $1,800 overnight.

summary: Lehman Brothers says a New York Giants financing unit is intentionally offering only documents that support the $301.8 million claim the football team made against the bank while withholding other information.

summary: Are NBA players the only athletes manly enough to go to  a fashion show?  LaBron James, Dwayne Wade and Amar'e Stoudemire at New York Fashion Week

headline: Brazil Trims Coffee Forecast
summary: The world's top coffee producer and exporter lowered its official estimate for the 2011 coffee crop but still expects the largest off-cycle harvest in more than a decade.

headline: Berkshire's New Hire Bears Shades of Buffett
summary: Ted Weschler, the second investment manager Berkshire Hathaway has tapped as an heir apparent to Warren Buffett, is a straight-shooter who, like the billionaire investor, brings along a philanthropic bent and a fondness for basic businesses.

headline: Canada's Household Debt Hits Record High
summary: Canadian appetite for debt showed no sign of lessening with a key indicator hitting a new high, as consumers borrowed to purchase houses and cars.

summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

summary: Paul Gigot's review of Dick Cheney's memoirs ("Mission Accomplished," Weekend Journal, Sept. 9) shows that the ex-vice president did indeed accomplished his mission.

summary: The phone-hacking scandal enveloping News Corp. has shut down a storied British newspaper, caused News Corp. to drop its bid for broadcaster BSkyB, and prompted hearings in U.K. Parliament. Here's a look at some of the key names in the ongoing saga.

summary: Jenny Packham is a favorite designer of the new Duchess of Cambridge, Kate Middleton. Below, a selection of looks from her Spring 2012 collection.

summary: This loft-like SoHo penthouse with four outdoor spaces has what its owner calls a 'yin and yang' aspect.

summary: China is set to launch a trial program that will end a 17-year ban on Chinese brokerages' presence in international futures markets.

summary: Novartis said it's on course to deliver strategic goals and that its recently acquired eye-care unit Alcon is poised to generate rapid long-term growth.

summary: Colfax's agreed $2.38 billion offer for Charter International is punchy, even if it's not quite the knock-out blow some investors expected.

summary: AMR's American Airlines will reduce its fourth-quarter capacity by 0.5% due to the "mixed economic environment" and a surge in pilot retirements.

headline: Long Sentence Urged in Insider Case

headline: Lehman Ex-Officials Blast Bid to Deny Funds

summary: Neiman Marcus reported a fiscal fourth-quarter loss as the upscale retailer posted a debt-related expense and slightly lower margins, but sales rose sharply.

headline: Capital Overload?
summary: Fast-growing emerging market economies are attracting soaring investment flows. See what the effects have been, and what the governments have tried to do about it.

summary: U.S. import prices fell in August, indicating inflation pressures are benign and providing U.S. policymakers with room to give the lackluster economy additional stimulus.

summary: With food prices relatively strong even during recent market turmoil, investors remain keen for exposure to agriculture. One popular theme: investing in land.

summary: Royal Philips Electronics said it plans to cut a further $410.4 million in costs as it confirmed its mid-term forecasts, despite the cooling global economy.

headline: Accor Sees No Sign of Slowdown
summary: French hotel group Accor forecast a strong performance in 2011 after a good summer, and Chief Executive Denis Hennequin said there was no sign of a slowdown in demand so far this year.

headline: TCS Says Outsourcing Demand Remains Solid

headline: Chrysler Says Union Deal Is Elusive
summary: Chrysler Group CEO Sergio Marchionne said the auto maker and the United Auto Workers are still divided on a number of issues, even as the current union contract is set to expire at midnight on Wednesday.

headline: Golden Bubbles
summary: A gold bubble in India is rapidly shaping, and if gold prices turn, it could become nasty for consumers, writes Samita Sawardekar.

headline: Peugeot-Citroen to Step Up Cost Cuts
summary: French car maker PSA Peugeot-Citroen plans to step up cost reductions amid an uncertain outlook for the automotive industry, and is in a stronger financial position than in 2008 before the previous crash, its chief executive said.

headline: ICC Cricket Awards 2011
summary: England's Jonathan Trott was named ICC cricketer of the year, while Mahendra Singh Dhoni's 'Spirit of Cricket' award was the only feather in India's cap. Some snapshots.

headline: AXA Expects Regulators to OK Reliance Deal By Year End

headline: Oil India to Sharply Raise Capex
summary: Oil India plans to raise its capital expenditure 73% to about 190 billion rupees ($4 billion) in the five years starting April 2012 as the state-run explorer seeks to sharply raise oil and gas production, its finance director said.

headline: Cairn Suffers Greenland Setback
summary: Shares in Cairn Energy fell sharply after the company suffered further disappointment in its controversial campaign exploring for oil and gas off the coast of Greenland.

headline: Moms Behind Israel's Tech Success
summary: Israel lives up to its reputation as the Start-up nation. Israeli start-ups are everywhere. It is what people aspire to. It is what they dream of.

headline: India to Rely on Free Trade Pacts
summary: India will keep signing free trade pacts with regional blocs and countries to boost merchandise exports, top officials said, as the World Trade Organization's Doha round of talks remains deadlocked and economies in traditional western markets struggle to recover.

summary: Workers at a development site, flood relief in Orissa, a fisherman in Gauhati and more. Some snapshots.

headline: Obama to Send Jobs Bill to Congress
summary: President Barack Obama will send his $447 billion jobs bill, the American Jobs Act, to Congress Monday night, a White House official said.

headline: Sara Lee Boots Executive
summary: Sara Lee backed off its earlier decision to have CJ Fraleigh, CEO of the North America division, run half the business when the food conglomerate splits in two next year. Fraleigh abruptly resigned.

headline: Setback in Bloomberg Case

headline: Nicolas Lecaussin: What's the Matter With the French Banks?
summary: Whether the market's worst fears are realized or not, the financial system maintains too close a relationship to the state.

headline: Obama's Jobs Speech Fails to Inspire Hope of Change
summary: President Obama is entirely disconnected from the one source of jobs that can revive his re-election hopes ("The Latest Jobs Plan," Review & Outlook, Sept. 9).

headline: Food Served With Fashion
summary: Finally, guests at a dinner for design label Rag & Bone rejoiced: a fashion event with food.

headline: Cochlear Recalls Line of Ear Implants
summary: Cochlear, the world's biggest maker of hearing implants, recalled its latest range of devices after a recent, unexplained increase in failures. The company's shares fell as much as 27%.

headline: Hayward to Cut Final BP Tie
summary: Former CEO will quit board of oil giant's Russian joint venture within weeks.

headline: ICB Takes Shot at Bank-Heavy Britain
summary: The U.K. Independent Commission on Banking proposal to radically shake up the banking industry is a major gamble, but one that policy makers seem happy to take.

summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for Sept. 13, 2011

summary: An interception and a dramatic blocked punt help seal a comeback victory over the Cowboys.

headline: McGurn: A Terror Consensus, but a Jobs Dispute
summary: Obama's economy is more divisive than Bush's response to 9/11.

headline: Founder Departs TechCrunch Blog
summary: Michael Arrington is leaving TechCrunch, the technology blog he founded in 2005 and sold to AOL for $30 million, for a recently formed venture fund, amid drama over his position at the company.

headline: The Dodd-Frank Layoffs
summary: As regulation cuts profits, Bank of America cuts 30,000 jobs.

headline: Some Strategists Are Sweet on Euro
summary: Several currency analysts at big banks are standing by predictions that the euro is set to vault higher, despite the sovereign-debt crisis in Europe.

headline: Democrats Boost Effort to Hold Seat
summary: A final rush of robo-calls, mailings and even a text message from President Barack Obama's campaign targeted voters in Brooklyn and Queens ahead of Tuesday's special election to pick a successor to Rep. Anthony Weiner.

headline: Banks Rethink Euro Forecasts
summary: Some of the biggest banks in foreign-exchange trading are reconsidering their euro forecasts in response to the deepening debt crisis in the currency region, but other high-profile players, including Deutsche Bank, are sticking to their positions.

headline: Revenge Feeds Instability in Libya
summary: Libya's National Transitional Council faces a struggle over how to reconcile the hatred between rebels and loyalists that bred during more than six months of fighting and dredged up old tribal feuds.

headline: Frictions Remain as U.K. Leader Visits Russia
summary: U.K. Prime Minister David Cameron sought to find common ground during the first visit by a British leader to Moscow in six years, but talks highlighted as much the lingering points of friction between the two sides.

headline: Phuket Villa
summary: This villa on the resort island of Phuket incorporates elements of traditional Thai design and includes a diverse collection of contemporary artwork.

headline: Bets on the 'Fear Index'  Scary for Most Investors
summary: In response to the market's recent swings, a growing number of investors are making bets on what looks like the only sure thing: market volatility itself. But the dazzling performance may blind some investors to the nuances of these investments.

headline: More Firms Root in Brooklyn
summary: Three small companies will bring about 60 jobs to the Brooklyn Army Terminal, showing that at least some industrial concerns are starting to expand in the city.

headline: Signs Grow for Global Slowdown
summary: Signs are growing stronger of a continuing slowdown in the world's largest economies, and it is increasingly clear the U.S. will share that fate, according to the OECD's composite leading indicators.

headline: Upsetting the Rugby Hierarchy
summary: After two decades of near domination from rugby's Goliaths, the most notable feature of the 2011 tournament's opening weekend was the growing threat that upstart teams pose to big names.

headline: Feud Killed Basketball Star

headline: Police Drug Count Dropped
summary: Manhattan prosecutors on Monday moved to drop drug-possession charges against a former New York City police officer who was acquitted of raping an intoxicated woman in her East Village apartment.

headline: Photos of the Day: Sept. 13
summary: In today's pictures, flooding returns to Pakistan, U.S. troops load a weapon in Afghanistan, a Libyan fighter holds up a bird at Gadhafi's compound, and more.

headline: French Art Deco Villa
summary: This six-bedroom home on the French Riviera's Cap Martin, ten minutes' drive from Monaco, overlooks the Mediterranean.

summary: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda sought to draw a line under a scandal that has rocked his fledgling administration, appointing popular lawmaker and former government spokesman Yukio Edano as the new industry minister after his predecessor made embarrassing remarks about the country's nuclear crisis.

headline: Macaw Mishap? Help Is On the Way
summary: A new system will greatly expand the number of codes used to describe medical services in bills to insurers. The new detail is welcome, but a few aspects are causing head scratching, including the nine codes available for injuries involving macaws.

summary: In 2006, Mimi O'Hagan, then in her late 70s, was in Ethiopia for a month constructing homes. When she returned home, she was emboldened with the idea to build a school.

headline: A Brooklyn Rap Crew Defies Its Name
summary: With its new album, Das Racist looks to outrun its past and prolong its future.

summary: Hurricane Irene, the storm that struck the East Coast late last month, could cost insurers up to $5.5 billion, according to a disaster-modeling company.

headline: An Achy, Aspirin-Packed Run for October

headline: Berkshire Adds Depth to Bench
summary: Berkshire Hathaway, Warren Buffett's investment vehicle, has named Ted Weschler to help manage the firm's equity portfolio.

summary: The U.K. banking industry faces a sweeping overhaul after an independent panel urged that retail businesses be segregated from investment-banking arms and higher capital buffers be imposed.

headline: Suzuki Requests Divorce From VW
summary: Suzuki decided to cancel its partnership with Volkswagen as talks between the companies became strained. VW said it has no plans to sell its shares.

headline: Taking the Dread Out of Phys Ed
summary: Tammy Brant, a gym teacher at Selma Middle School, in Selma, Ind., is rethinking the way schools teach girls and boys about fitness.

headline: E. Coli Ban Proposed for 6 More Strains
summary: The Department of Agriculture plans to add six types of E. coli bacteria to its list of adulterants barred from raw beef sold in stores.

headline: On Your Mark, Get Set, Hack!
summary: Hackathons, once an obscure corner of the computer programming world, are becoming more mainstream.

headline: A Star Attraction Does Her Thing
summary: CNN legal correspondent and New Yorker writer Jeffrey Toobin hosted a party at his Upper West Side apartment for Allison Pearson, to celebrate the opening of the film "I Don't Know How She Does It."
